para.paratext: A collateral agreement that does not contradict or vary the terms of the writing is not merged in the writing and may be shown by parol evidence, if not within the statute of frauds.

It is often difficult to determine if the offered agreement is collateral. A New York case stated a good test: (1) The agreement must be collateral in form, (2) it must not contradict or vary the written contract, and (3) it must be one that parties would not ordinarily be expected to embody in the writing.[1]

The Georgia Supreme Court did not use any specific requirements in determining that the agreement was collateral to, independent of, and distinct from the written contract in Langenback v. Mays.[2] However, many opinions contain the statement: “before parol evidence can be admitted to show a collateral agreement it must appear from the contract itself or from the attendant circumstances that the contract is incomplete and that what is sought to be shown as a collateral agreement does not in any way conflict with or contradict what is contained in the writing.”[3]
The courts may have confused incomplete writings with the use of the parol rule with collateral agreements. If the writing is incomplete, then there is no need for the collateral agreement exception.

In a vendor-purchaser relationship involving the sale of realty, the executory contract for the sale of realty is normally merged into the deed which executes the contract. However, duties and obligations to be performed after delivery of the deed, usually by the vendor, are not merged into the deed and are collateral agreements. For this exception to apply, the pleadings must allege that the parties intended certain obligations to survive the deed and that there is nothing in the contract or deed to show a different intent. The court will apply the doctrine of merger absent such an allegation of intent.[4]

Although this exception is well established, there is variation of application to specific situations.[5] The exception has been applied to permit enforcement of agreements to complete improvements after closing,[6] to guarantee a dry basement for one year,[7] and to guarantee that a fireplace works.[8]

In Georgia Mobile Home Development Corp. v. Kutor,[9] the contract contained a provision that the parties “agree that such papers as may be legally necessary to carry out the terms of this contract shall be executed and delivered by such parties at time sale is consummated.” The court held that, absent any other evidence of intent, a provision in the contract for payment of $59 a year for recreational facilities was merged into the deed which did not contain any such provision.
Langenback v. Mays, 205 Ga. 706, 54 S.E.2d 401, 11 A.L.R.2d 1221 (1949).
See Forsyth Mfg. Co. v. Castlen, 112 Ga. 199, 37 S.E. 485 (1900).
